verses.text: In the twenty-third year of Joash son of Ahaziah, king of Judah, Jehoahaz son of Jehu became king over Israel in Samaria, and he reigned seventeen years.
verses.comment: Faithfully translated. Significant rulers and chronology retained.

verses.text: He did evil in the sight of the LORD and followed the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, which he made Israel to sin. He did not depart from them.
verses.comment: Kept the phrase 'in the sight of the LORD' for faithfulness.

verses.text: So the anger of the LORD was kindled against Israel, and he delivered them continually into the hand of Hazael king of Syria, and into the hand of Ben-hadad the son of Hazael.
verses.comment: Kept 'kindled' and phrase 'the hand of' for accuracy.

verses.text: Then Jehoahaz sought the favor of the LORD, and the LORD listened to him, for he saw the oppression of Israel, because the king of Syria oppressed them.
verses.comment: 'Sought the favor' is a literal rendering of 'pleaded.'

verses.text: So the LORD gave Israel a deliverer, so that they escaped from the hand of the Syrians; and the people of Israel lived in their tents as before.
verses.comment: 'Lived in their tents' means lived peacefully as before; reflects the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Nevertheless they did not depart from the sins of the house of Jeroboam, which he made Israel to sin, but walked in them; the Asherah also remained in Samaria.
verses.comment: Kept 'walked in them' for literalness; Asherah refers to the idolatrous pole.

verses.text: For he left to Jehoahaz of the army nothing but fifty horsemen and ten chariots and ten thousand foot soldiers, for the king of Syria had destroyed them and made them like the dust at threshing.
verses.comment: 'Made them like the dust at threshing' is a literal translation.

verses.text: Now the rest of the deeds of Jehoahaz, all that he did, and his might, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?
verses.comment: Standard formula phrase.

verses.text: So Jehoahaz slept with his fathers, and they buried him in Samaria. And Joash his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: 'Slept with his fathers' is a traditional phrase, kept for accuracy.

verses.text: In the thirty-seventh year of Joash king of Judah, Jehoash son of Jehoahaz began to reign over Israel in Samaria, and he reigned sixteen years.
verses.comment: Joash and Jehoash are the same person; maintained name mapping.

verses.text: He also did what was evil in the sight of the LORD. He did not depart from any of the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, which he made Israel to sin, but he walked in them.
verses.comment: Same repeated formula used of earlier kings.

verses.text: Now the rest of the deeds of Joash, all that he did, and his might, and how he fought with Amaziah king of Judah, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?
verses.comment: Preserves the common historical conclusion formula.

verses.text: So Joash slept with his fathers, and Jeroboam sat on his throne. Joash was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel.
verses.comment: 'Jeroboam sat on his throne' refers to Jeroboam II, Joash's son.

verses.text: Now Elisha had fallen sick with the illness of which he would die. Joash king of Israel went down to him and wept over him, and said, 'My father, my father! The chariots of Israel and its horsemen!'
verses.comment: 'My father' shows respect to the prophet. Direct quote retained.

verses.text: And Elisha said to him, 'Take a bow and arrows.' So he took a bow and arrows.
verses.comment: Literal rendering of the prophet's words.

verses.text: Then he said to the king of Israel, 'Draw the bow.' And he drew it. And Elisha laid his hands on the king’s hands.
verses.comment: Literal rendering; action is sequential in Hebrew.

verses.text: And he said, 'Open the east window.' So he opened it. Then Elisha said, 'Shoot,' and he shot. And he said, 'The LORD’s arrow of victory, the arrow of victory over Syria! You shall strike the Syrians in Aphek until you have destroyed them.'
verses.comment: The prophetic action and word-for-word dialogue kept for literal accuracy.

verses.text: And he said, 'Take the arrows.' So he took them. And he said to the king of Israel, 'Strike the ground with them.' So he struck three times and stopped.
verses.comment: Kept literal instruction, underscoring the king’s insufficient zeal.

verses.text: Then the man of God was angry with him and said, 'You should have struck five or six times; then you would have struck down Syria until you had destroyed it. But now you will strike Syria only three times.'
verses.comment: Dialogue closely follows Hebrew structure.

verses.text: So Elisha died, and they buried him. Now bands of Moabite raiders would invade the land in the spring every year.
verses.comment: ‘Moabite raiders’ literal, preserves reference to seasonal raids.

verses.text: As they were burying a man, suddenly they saw a raiding band, so they threw the man into the tomb of Elisha. As soon as the man touched Elisha’s bones, he revived and stood up on his feet.
verses.comment: Phrase 'stood up on his feet' echoes the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Now Hazael king of Syria oppressed Israel all the days of Jehoahaz.
verses.comment: Simple literal rendering.

verses.text: But the LORD was gracious to them and had compassion on them and turned toward them because of his covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and would not destroy them, nor has he cast them from his presence until now.
verses.comment: 'Has he cast them from his presence until now' is a literal rendering of a Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: When Hazael king of Syria died, Ben-hadad his son reigned in his place.
verses.comment: Retains Hebrew lineage phrasing.

verses.text: Then Jehoash son of Jehoahaz took back from Ben-hadad son of Hazael the towns that he had taken from Jehoahaz his father in war. Three times Jehoash defeated him and recovered the cities of Israel.
verses.comment: 'Jehoash' and 'Joash' refer to the same king; name maintained for accuracy.
